head.title: Commodore Vanderbilt Would Have Loved It

hedline.hl1: Commodore Vanderbilt Would Have Loved It

abstract.p: Alfred G Vanderbilt letter on July 18 article on New York City's war against billboard-toting tugboat recalls his ancestor's successful battle against city's effort to impose its laws on New Jersey residents

block.p: Your July 18 news article about the battle between New York City officials and the company behind Gunny, a billboard-toting tugboat, should prove that failing to learn from history dooms us to repeat it.

Your July 18 news article about the battle between New York City officials and the company behind Gunny, a billboard-toting tugboat, should prove that failing to learn from history dooms us to repeat it.
Chased into New Jersey waters, the Gunny continues to be threatened by city officials who claim they can enforce their laws against advertising on waterways in another state.

In the early 1800's, New York's Legislature granted Robert Fulton's steamship company exclusive operating rights to its waters. Cornelius Vanderbilt (my great-great-great-grandfather), who was employed in New Jersey, argued that no state should be allowed to make laws binding the residents of another. He boldly sailed into New York Harbor under a banner proclaiming ''New Jersey Must Be Free!'' His lawyer, Daniel Webster, argued the case before the Supreme Court and won, thus prompting the first laws of interstate commerce.
''DIRTPILE.com,'' the message on the Gunny's 72-foot sign, may not convey quite the same lilt as the words on the Commodore's flag. But I imagine he would have nevertheless enjoyed the fight.
ALFRED G. VANDERBILT Rowayton, Conn., July 24, 2000
